Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: The deadline for closing the books for the month is approaching.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Mom just as I was double-checking the quarterly expense reports. “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glanced at the clock—already past 8 p.m. on Sunday. I hadn’t called home all week, only sent a quick text on Saturday. Guilt pricked at me; I knew how much my parents valued hearing my voice, especially since I moved out. But the numbers on my screen demanded my attention. The month-end close was looming, and I still had to reconcile two more accounts before tomorrow’s deadline. My manager had reminded us all how crucial accuracy was, and I couldn’t afford a mistake. I stared at my phone, torn. If I called home now, I’d lose precious time and risk missing errors. If I waited, I’d disappoint my parents again. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I sat frozen, unable to choose which role to let down tonight.
